text: Morning fog slid down from the distant mountains, spreading along the stone-paved streets into the town center. Firelight wavered against the glass. Outside, the snow hadn’t stopped, and the sky was grey, dull as old iron.
The inn was heavy with damp air, mixed with the lingering smell of last night’s smoke. I stood behind the counter wiping glasses, my knuckles numb with cold.
This was usually the most ordinary moment of the day—before travelers arrived, when there was nothing but the echo of glass and my own breathing.
But today was different.
The door was kicked open. A rush of alcohol and freezing wind poured in, snow forced through the doorway and scattered across the floor.
"Wine! Fucking hell, another jug!" he roared as he barged in, his eyes bloodshot, his leather armor creased and cracked, dried blood clinging to the corner of his mouth.
"Drinking this early? Come on, man—the town guard will be around soon. You’re in no state. Go home and rest."
"You fucking telling me what to do?!"
He grabbed me by the collar, the force nearly hauling me over the counter.
His fist slammed into me. My vision lurched, blood seeping from my gums. A few patrons hurried into the corners—no one dared step in.
Just then, footsteps sounded at the door.
Not hurried, but slow and steady—like someone walking a path they had already taken countless times.
A woman in a silver-white cloak stepped inside. Frost still clung to her armor, and her silver hair caught the morning light, cold and sharp.
She swept her gaze across the tavern, her eyes flat, like she was looking at a painting she had long grown tired of.
"A pot of hot water."
Her voice held no inflection, as if the chaos before her was nothing more than background noise.
The drunk glanced at her and sneered. "What, another one here to watch the show?"
I coughed up a mouthful of bloody spit and forced the words out. "…You’re not going to do something about this?"
She looked at me briefly. There was no malice in her eyes—and no pity.
"I’ve helped plenty of times before."
The drunk’s gaze lingered for half a second on the sword at her waist, its cracks even deeper. It wasn’t fear—more like calculation.
"You compensate me—fill a jug to go. Call it cooling me off."
"You just hit someone—"
"Cut the shit! Either you pour the booze, or I tear your tables apart and burn them for firewood."
Alicia sat there, gently stirring her hot water without lifting her eyes. Her silence felt like a wall.
I swallowed my anger and ladled wine into his filthy leather flask. The liquid splashed over my knuckles, ice-cold and numbing.
"Now that’s more like it."
"Remember—next time you see me, don’t drag your feet."
He flicked a chipped copper coin onto the counter. It clinked against the wood—not like payment, more like alms.
"I’m in a good mood today—won’t smash your place."
He laughed as he walked away, the crunch of boots on snow swallowed by the wind.
The tavern fell quiet again. I held my face—my palm was warm, yet I felt cold.
"…Do you know me?"
"The key’s under the carpet, right? I’ll be staying the night."
She went upstairs. That hiding place for the key was something only regulars knew.
